info.game_comments:
2006 Celebrity Jeopardy! game 10.
From Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

(1, 1).clue: Third in line to the British throne, he came into the world September 15, 1984

(2, 1).clue: The Korean War lasted 3 years, but this TV show set in the Korean War lasted 11

(3, 1).clue: The ancient monument known as Stonehenge is found in this country

(4, 1).clue: You gotta break some eggs to make this item; in 1994, 160,000 were used to make a 1,383-square-foot one

(5, 1).clue: We might recite these jokes whose second line is always "Who's there?"

(6, 1).clue: This type of screw head has two partial slots crossed at right angles

(1, 2).clue: The 1987 book "And the Band Played On" alerted many Americans to this disease

(2, 2).clue: Chuck Barris created & hosted this show, a sort of talent-free show

(3, 2).clue: The "henge" part of the word Stonehenge is a term meaning an ancient monument arranged in this shape

(4, 2).clue: At Marshall Field's in 2002, life was like a 3,226-pound box of this

(6, 2).clue: "Here lies Lester Moore / Four slugs from a .44 / No Les, no more" is a marker at this cemetery in Tombstone, Az.

(1, 3).clue: On April 29, 1994 this man was elected president of South Africa in that country's first interracial national election

(2, 3).clue: The Fonz told people to "Sit on it!" on this show that debuted in 1974

(3, 3).clue: One legend says that this magician who helped King Arthur used his powers to build Stonehenge

(4, 3).clue: Run as fast as you can, you can't catch this treat; one made in 2003 was 13' 11" in height

(6, 3).clue: On January 10, 1982 the temperature in Chicago was -26 degrees F.; this made it feel like -81 degrees F.

(1, 4).clue: The U.S. launched Operation Desert Shield soon after Iraq's August 2, 1990 invasion of this country

(2, 4).clue: Tom Selleck appeared as rival detective Lance White on this show that starred James Garner

(3, 4).clue: Today some archaeologists believe that Stonehenge was used to track & observe these 2 heavenly bodies

(4, 4).clue: Yes, we have one bunch of these, 473 individual ones in a bunch grown in Spain in 2001

(6, 4).clue: Informally, if something is worth virtually nothing at all, it "doesn't amount to" this 3-word food term

(1, 5).clue: In 1999, this 6-year-old Cuban refugee was the subject of a custody battle

(2, 5).clue: The theme song to this sitcom said, "Well we're moving on up, to the east side"

(3, 5).clue: During the summer solstice, modern-day people who act like these Celtic priests hold cermonies at Stonehenge

(4, 5).clue: In 1993 chefs from Glasgow's Hilton & others used 80 ox stomachs to make the largest this on record--668 lbs.!  Och aye!

(6, 5).clue: A great Greek warrior, or a tendon attached to the heel

(1, 1).clue: In geography, you should know that this South American river has the world's largest drainage system

(2, 1).clue: In Italian, to wish someone "buona fortuna" is to wish them this

(3, 1).clue: "Maximus Decimus Meridius... father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife, and I will have my vengeance"

(4, 1).clue: A member of this comedy team, Harpo was a virtuoso on the harp & played it in some of their movies

(5, 1).clue: Call this company, VZ, if you want to hear me now

(6, 1).clue: Einstein published the special theory of this in 1905; the general theory of it was announced in 1915

(1, 2).clue: Learn the basics of chemistry, like this chemical formula for water

(2, 2).clue: It's the rhyming way you'd say "please" to your Spanish-speaking friend

(3, 2).clue: "Now... bring me that horizon.  'And really bad eggs.'  Drink up me hearties yo ho"

(4, 2).clue: Of 7, 47 or 147, the number of strings on a modern pedal harp

(5, 2).clue: Some people said presidential hopeful John Kerry was in bed with this company, HNZ

(6, 2).clue: Rockets produce 7 million pounds of thrust during takeoff of this vehicle, the space transportation system

(1, 3).clue: Civics class taught you the Declaration of Independence lists these 3 "unalienable rights"
(1, 3).correct response: life, liberty & the pursuit of happiness

(2, 3).clue: As a sign of respect, this word used as a suffix after a Japanese name should never be used after your own

(3, 3).clue: "I remember every detail.  The Germans wore gray, you wore blue"

(4, 3).clue: The harp is a national symbol of this European country & also the name of a popular beer from that country

(5, 3).clue: This company, XOM, is mobile because they're full of gas

(6, 3).clue: This branch of physics focuses on radioactivity; this type of family has a mother, father & children

(1, 4).clue: Get some Latin under your belt, like amo, amas & this third-person singular form of "to love"

(2, 4).clue: Seen here is this word that you should have down cold before visiting Russia, where you'll be downing it cold

(3, 4).clue: "I tell you things, you tell me things, not about this case, though, about yourself. Quid pro quo... yes or no, Clarice?"

(4, 4).clue: If you have a drafty house, you can play the Aeolian harp; its strings are sounded not by hands but this

(5, 4).clue: This company, TWX, likes initials such as AOL, HBO & TBS

(6, 4).clue: As you know, Dr., the frontal this in the brain is key to emotion & reason; stay away from the one on the ear this time

(1, 5).clue: God willing, you'll learn enough about religion to know this word defined as belief in a single god

(2, 5).clue: "Magandang umaga", Tagalog for "good morning", would come in handiest in this world capital

(3, 5).clue: "I know that you & Frank were planning to disconnect me, & that's something I cannot allow to happen"

(4, 5).clue: In the Bible, this ancient Hebrew king & psalmist played a harp called a kinnor

(5, 5).clue: This food company, MCD, gobbled up Boston Market & Chipotle Mexican Grill

(0, 0).clue: Among the many movies that have premiered here at Radio City Music Hall was this 1962 film based on a novel by Harper Lee
